{{also|Bräuchen}} ==German== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|de|bʰruHg}} From {{inh|de|goh|brūhhan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*brūkaną||use, employ, consume}}. English ''[[brook#Etymology 1|brook]]'' is cognate. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈbraʊ̯x(ə)n/}} * {{audio|de|De-brauchen.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-brauchen.ogg|audio (Austria)}} * {{hyphenation|de|brau|chen}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-irregular|braucht|brauchte|gebraucht|past subjunctive=[[bräuchte]] or [[brauchte]]}} # to [[need]], to be in need of #: {{ux|de|Ich '''brauche''' deine Hilfe.|t=I need your help.}} # to [[need]] to, to have to (in negation or with the adverb {{m|de|nur||just, only}}) #: {{ux|de|Du '''brauchst''' nicht auf mich (zu) warten.|t=You don’t need to wait for me.}} #: {{ux|de|Sie '''braucht''' mich nur an(zu)rufen.|t=She just needs to call me.}} ====Usage notes==== * Traditionally, ''brauchen'' has been a weak verb in standard German with a regular past subjunctive ''brauchte''. However, the irregular form ''br'''ä'''uchte'' has since found its way from the dialects into the standard. It is already the ''only'' common form in spoken Germanhttp://www.atlas-alltagssprache.de/r8-f4m-2/, and is gradually becoming dominant in writing as well (although some grammars may still discourage this usage). * In colloquial German, the verb may be even further assimilated to modal verbs by taking a bare infinitive instead of a ''zu'' infinitive (''du brauchst nicht schreien'' instead of standard ''du brauchst nicht'' zu ''schreien'') and sometimes by taking an endingless third-person singular present (''er brauch'', instead of ''er brauch'''t'''''). Both of these are properties of modal verbs, cf. ''er'' {{m|de|soll}} ''gehen'', ''er'' {{m|de|muss}} ''bleiben''. ====Conjugation==== regular: {{de-conj-weak|brauch|gebraucht|h}} irregular: {{de-conj-strong|brauch|brauch|gebraucht|h|||bräuch}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|gebrauchen}} * {{l|de|verbrauchen}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|Brauch}} * {{l|de|brauchbar}} ===References=== ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} ---- ==Luxembourgish== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|lb|bʰruHg}} From {{inh|lb|goh|brūhhan}}, from {{inh|lb|gem-pro|*brūkaną}}.
